ovdesc.p: The MG.PAYMENT application allows for the input of manual principal redemptions or early contract closure. The following is a brief summary of some of the functions and features of this application.
This routine only allows for the repayment of principal. It is not possible to specify an amount of interest or any additional payment elements to be paid.

The payment amount is entered on the payment record, although if a transaction type of "closure" is specified this will be done automatically. If the contract is being closed, ie. the total outstanding principal is being repaid, then any outstanding interest on the contract will also be paid.

The payment amount will be debited to an account specified on the payment record which is where the client is expected to deliver (credit) the funds. This account need not belong to the client but may belong to a third party, i.e. a solicitor, or be an internal account.
Any payment entered via this application must be made with a value date equal to or less than the current system date. It is not possible to enter a forward dated payment.

However, it is possible to back value a payment into a previous interest/repayment period. In this case any existing repayments, with a value date after that of the payment being entered, will be adjusted. This effectively results in these repayments being reversed and then reprocessed taking into account any changes in principal balance and accrued interest resulting from the input of this payment.
Similarly an old payment entered via this routine may be reversed at any time. If subsequent repayments have been made then these will be adjusted in the same way as described above.
It is not possible to reverse a payment which results in the closure of the contract, i.e. the principal has been reduced to zero.

In the case of redemption type contracts, ie. ANNUITY and LINEAR types, the reduction in the outstanding principal will have an effect on the future repayment scheme. If scheduled repayments are maintained at their old value the contract will be repaid earlier.

It is possible when entering a payment to request that the system recalculate, the repayment amount in order to maintain the original term of the contract. An effective date for this new amount is also calculated. Both will be transferred to the contract record after authorisation and will come into effect on the calculated date.
The calculated amount and effective date may be overridden if required or the original repayment amount may be retained and the contract repaid early.

If required, it is possible to levy a number of charges in respect of the payment via this routine. This feature makes use of the standard charge codes and default amounts on the FT.CHARGE.TYPE table. Charge amounts are debited to an account specified by user or to the account specified for receipt of the payment amount.

Identifies any new repayment amount requested on a redemption type contract as a result of the reduced outstanding principal on the contract.

This field is used to change the repayment amount on a redemption type contract. For these contract types the change in the outstanding balance of the contract, brought about by the input of this payment, will have an effect on future repayments and the final maturity of the contract. The customer may wish to see the periodic repayments on the loan reduced as a result of this redemption; alternatively they may be left at the same level in which case the loan will be repaid earlier.

If the repayment amount is to be changed then the new desired amount may be entered here. The date on which this new amount becomes effective is entered in the NEW.REPAY.DATE field. If an automatic recalculation of the repayment amount has been requested via the RECALC.REPAYMENT field then the first possible date on which the new repayment amount may come into effect will have already been defaulted into the NEW.REPAY.DATE field.

Whenever a new repayment amount is requested, either via input to this field or the RECALC.REPAYMENT field, the system will automatically calculate a new theoretical repayment amount. This amount represents the minimum repayment amount required to repay the loan based on the contract parameters on the NEW.REPAY.DATE. This theoretical amount will be inserted in the NEW.THEORETICAL field and used to validate this field.

A number of new amounts and dates may be entered if required. These amounts are validated in such a way that the contract will always be repaid within the term. If multiple new amounts are present then the intermediate actual amounts may be less than their associated theoretical amounts, however, the final repayment amount must be at least as great as the final theoretical amount.

It should be noted that this multivalue set of fields, NEW.REPAY.AMT to NEW.THEORETICAL, have equivalent fields on the contract record on the MG.MORTGAGE file. If any new repayment details are present on the contract record at the time of input of a payment then these will be automatically entered on the payment record prior to any user input to that record.
After authorisation of the payment these fields will be transferred to their equivalents on the contract record on the MG.MORTGAGE file.

Contains all the Override messages which the user agreed to during Input.

During the validation of a payment the system may provide the user with a series of screen override messages to indicate an anomaly; for instance, if the value date of the payment entered is not a working day.
In the event the user confirming the Override, the full text of the actual Override Message will be stored for reference purposes only in this multivalue field.
In the example given above when the deal is validated a warning bell will sound and a message will appear, at the foot of the screen, which reads:
'VALUE DATE IS NOT A WORKING DAY'
This will draw the user's attention to the amount entered, which may be a mistake and can then be corrected, or, on the other hand, it may be correct and can be confirmed as so.

A second example might be where the payment amount debiting the payment account causes this account to be overdrawn. In this case, when the deal is validated, a warning bell will sound and a message will appear, at the foot of the screen, which reads:
'ACCOUNT 0221000178 - UNAUTHORISED OVERDRAFT'
Once again the user's attention is drawn to the situation and either corrected or confirmed via a positive response to the Override Message.

Uniquely identifies the payment and the contract to which it relates.

Any number of manual payments may be entered for a single contract, however, each has its own unique ID. This consists of the contract number and a sequential payment number which uniquely identifies individual payments. The contract to which the payment relates must be manually entered but the payment number will automatically default from the MG.PAYMENT.CONTROL file. The way in which this is done depends on the function required as follows:
(I)nput

If an unauthorised payment record exists then the number of this will be defaulted, if not, the next sequence number available will be taken. For example, if two payment records have already been entered for this contract (nos. 1 and 2) then the payment number will default to 3.
(D)elete and (A)uthorise
The payment number of any unauthorised payment will default.
Note: For the above functions it is not possible to enter any payment other than the one that will default.
(R)everse
The most recent payment entered, ie the highest payment number, will default. If the reversal of an earlier payment is required then the payment number must be entered manually.
(S)ee and (P)rint

If an unauthorised payment exists this will default, otherwise the most recent payment number, ie the highest, will be taken. If a prior payment record is required then the payment number must be entered manually.

The contract number portion of the ID may also be entered in shorthand format. It is not necessary to enter the "MG" module prefix or any leading zeroes in the sequence number portion of the contract number. For more details on the structure of the contract ID and the shorthand method of input, refer to the MG.MORTGAGE helptext.

Defines the type of transaction being entered.

The value entered in this field determines the type of transaction being processed. This will determine the transaction codes used and therefore the narrative appearing on the customers's statement. The following types are available:
1. REDEMPTION

This type should be used for the input of partial redemption transactions, where an amount of principal less than the outstanding balance of the loan is being repaid. The value date for this type of transaction can be any date prior to the current date and may be prior to a previous repayment date if required. The transaction code used for this type is 810. Any adjustments to existing payments caused by this transaction being backdated prior to a previous repayment, will raise entries using the transaction codes 814 and 816 for principal and interest respectively.
2. CLOSURE

This type of transaction can only be used to close or fully repay a contract. It is not necessary to enter the PAYMENT.AMOUNT as this will automatically default to the outstanding principal on the contract. Interest will be accrued up to the payment date in the VALUE.DATE field and this and any other outstanding interest will also be repaid, however this amount is not included in that shown in the PAYMENT.AMOUNT field. The transaction codes used for the accounting entries raised are 810 and 804 for principal and interest respectively.
CLOSURE type transactions cannot be reversed.
3. ADJUSTMENT
This type is similar to REDEMPTION except that the transaction code used for the debit entry of the PAYMENT.AMOUNT is 814.

Specifies the effective date of any new repayment amounts entered in the NEW.REPAY.AMT field. For redemption type contracts the change in the outstanding principal balance on the contract will effect the future repayments on that contract and the date of final maturity. The customer of the loan may wish to see the periodic repayment amount of the loan reduced to reflect the lower outstanding balance. Alternatively, he may wish this amount to remain the same thereby bringing forward the maturity date. If the repayment amount is to be changed then this field is used to define the date on which the new repayment amount becomes effective. This date may be input manually or defaulted by the system. Defaulting of this field is achieved by requesting a recalculation of the repayment amount via the RECALC.REPAYMENT field. In this case the next repayment date after which the principal amount, and in the case of annuity loans the interest rate, have remained unchanged for a full repayment period will be defaulted. It should be noted that this multivalue set of fields, NEW.REPAY.AMT to NEW.THEORETICAL, have equivalent fields on the contract record on the MG.MORTGAGE file. If any new repayment details are present on the contract record at the time of input of the payment then these will be automatically entered on the payment record prior to any user input to that record. After authorisation of the payment these fields will be transferred to their equivalents on the contract record on the MG.MORTGAGE file.

In the event the user confirming the Override, the full text of the actual Override Message will be stored for reference purposes only in this multivalue field. In the example given above when the deal is validated a warning bell will sound and a message will appear, at the foot of the screen, which reads: 'VALUE DATE IS NOT A WORKING DAY' This will draw the user's attention to the amount entered, which may be a mistake and can then be corrected, or, on the other hand, it may be correct and can be confirmed as so. Uniquely identifies the payment and the contract to which it relates. Any number of manual payments may be entered for a single contract, however, each has its own unique ID. This consists of the contract number and a sequential payment number which uniquely identifies individual payments. The contract to which the payment relates must be manually entered but the payment number will automatically default from the MG.PAYMENT.CONTROL file. The way in which this is done depends on the function required as follows: (I)nput If an unauthorised payment record exists then the number of this will be defaulted, if not, the next sequence number available will be taken. For example, if two payment records have already been entered for this contract (nos. 1 and 2) then the payment number will default to 3. (D)elete and (A)uthorise The payment number of any unauthorised payment will default. Note: For the above functions it is not possible to enter any payment other than the one that will default. (R)everse The most recent payment entered, ie the highest payment number, will default. If the reversal of an earlier payment is required then the payment number must be entered manually. (S)ee and (P)rint If an unauthorised payment exists this will default, otherwise the most recent payment number, ie the highest, will be taken. If a prior payment record is required then the payment number must be entered manually. The contract number portion of the ID may also be entered in shorthand format. It is not necessary to enter the "MG" module prefix or any leading zeroes in the sequence number portion of the contract number. For more details on the structure of the contract ID and the shorthand method of input, refer to the MG.MORTGAGE helptext.

STMT.NO

A number generated automatically by the system which identifies either a statement entry or a category entry in respect of a contract. Whenever a payment is entered via this application a number of accounting entries will be raised. This field will record the IDs of the entries generated. The IDs to accounting entries, both STMT.ENTRYs and CATEG.ENTRYs, consist of a date-time stamp and a sequence number. All entries raised by a particular input/transaction will have the same date-time stamp but different sequence numbers. This field has three multivalues, the first contains the base date-time stamp which is common to all entries. The second contains the sequence numbers of the STMT.ENTRYs raised and the third the sequence numbers of any CATEG.ENTRYs. The examples on the following pages illustrate the use of this field more clearly. Example 1: When a payment record is authorised a debit entry for the payment amount will be posted to the account entered PAYMENT.ACCOUNT field. The system will generate a statement entry and record the ID of the entry in this field as follows: 22.1 STMT.NO ............ 673732684.48 22.2 STMT.NO ............ 1 The number automatically generated in Field 22.1 is unique to the payment in question and is built up in the following way: 1. The first four digits '6737' indicate the number of days since the 1st of January 1968. In our example it corresponds to the 11th of June 1986. 2. The next five digits '32684' indicate the number of seconds since midnight. In our example it corresponds to an entry generated on line at 09:04:44 AM. 3. The last two digits '48' indicate the number of hundreds of seconds. The value assigned to Field 22.2 identifies the number in 22.1 as a statement entry number. This entry can be seen via the STMT.ENTRY Application using the the ID: 673732684.480001 where the suffix '0001' identifies it as the first statement entry (there may be more than one as the next example will illustrate). Example 2: A second example might be that of a payment where two separate charges have been levied. The payment itself will generate a debit statement entry as in the previous example. However, the addition of charges will generate a further two statement entries debiting the charge account for the amount of each charge, as well as a category entry crediting the relevant P&L category code(s). The IDs of the entries generated will be recorded as follows: 22.1 STMT.NO ............ 673732684.48 22.2 STMT.NO ............ 1 - 3 22.3 STMT.NO ............ 1 - 2 Once again the standard date-time stamp is generated and inserted in Field 22.1. Now, however, both fields 22.2 and 22.3 contain a value. The value in field 22.2 now indicates that three statement entries have been raised and in field 22.3 that two category entries have also been raised. To view these entries the STMT.ENTRY and now the CATEG.ENTRY application should be used. In this case the IDs required for each application are: STMT.ENTRY 673732684.480001 673732684.480002 673732684.480003 CATEG.ENTRY 673732684.480001 673732684.480001

TRANSACTION.TYPE

Defines the type of transaction being entered. The value entered in this field determines the type of transaction being processed. This will determine the transaction codes used and therefore the narrative appearing on the customers's statement. The following types are available: 1. REDEMPTION This type should be used for the input of partial redemption transactions, where an amount of principal less than the outstanding balance of the loan is being repaid. The value date for this type of transaction can be any date prior to the current date and may be prior to a previous repayment date if required. The transaction code used for this type is 810. Any adjustments to existing payments caused by this transaction being backdated prior to a previous repayment, will raise entries using the transaction codes 814 and 816 for principal and interest respectively. 2. CLOSURE This type of transaction can only be used to close or fully repay a contract. It is not necessary to enter the PAYMENT.AMOUNT as this will automatically default to the outstanding principal on the contract. Interest will be accrued up to the payment date in the VALUE.DATE field and this and any other outstanding interest will also be repaid, however this amount is not included in that shown in the PAYMENT.AMOUNT field. The transaction codes used for the accounting entries raised are 810 and 804 for principal and interest respectively. CLOSURE type transactions cannot be reversed. 3. ADJUSTMENT This type is similar to REDEMPTION except that the transaction code used for the debit entry of the PAYMENT.AMOUNT is 814.
Validation Rules

1 - 12 alpha character. Must be either (R)EDEMPTION, (C)LOSURE or (A)DJUSTMENT. If interest has already been accrued on the contract beyond this date, then the accrual will be adjusted. Similarly, if this date is prior to that of an earlier payment or scheduled repayment, then these repayment amounts will be adjusted and re-posted.
